content: Congress finds that the Russian Government has blocked Ukrainian access to accurate information, while US international programming aims to promote democratic governance. The opinions of Ukrainians, especially in eastern regions and Crimea, are misrepresented in Russian media. Russian forces have seized TV stations in Crimea for propaganda purposes. The United States aims to combat Russian propaganda in Ukraine by increasing international programming. Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty and Voice of America will provide credible news, investigative journalism, and prioritize areas with limited access to uncensored information, especially in eastern Ukraine and Crimea. The United States aims to combat Russian propaganda in Ukraine by increasing international programming. Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty and Voice of America will prioritize programming to eastern Ukraine, Crimea, Moldova, ethnic Russian populations, and Tatar minorities. They will focus on news and information that enhances understanding of political and economic developments in Ukraine and Moldova, countering misinformation from Russian-supported news outlets. The United States aims to combat Russian propaganda in Ukraine by increasing international programming. Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty and Voice of America will provide 24/7 programming to target populations in Ukrainian, Russian, and Tatar languages through various distribution outlets. This includes original television and video content as well as audio content distributed on satellite, digital, and regional affiliates. Additionally, they will expand mobile news and multimedia platforms for audience engagement. Authorization of Appropriations: Up to $10,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2014 to enhance programming in Ukrainian, Balkan, Russian, and Tatar languages by RFE/RL, Incorporated, and Voice of America. This funding aims to strengthen existing US programming in Ukraine and neighboring regions, increase programming capacity, and improve jamming circumvention technology. The Broadcasting Board of Governors must submit a detailed report to Congress within 15 days of the enactment of the Act regarding plans to increase broadcasts in specified languages.
